bibl.title: Letter from James D. Baker to Philip Showalter Hench, December 19, 1952

div1.p: Baker is sending Hench clippings of two articles that appeared in “Excelsior.” He regrets that the reporter published the articles without allowing Rojas and Baker check them, but thinks that the reporter explained cortisone use fairly well.

div1.head: Letter from James D. Baker to Philip Showalter Hench, December 19, 1952
div1.opener:
JAMES D. BAKER
DIRECTOR
RUSTON ACADEMY
Quinta y G. - Vedado
Habana, Cuba
DECEMBER 19, 1952
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DEAR DR. HENCH:
div1.p:
ENCLOSED YOU WILL FIND CLIPPINGS OF THE TWO ARTICLES
WHICH APPEARED IN EXCELSIOR ON THE TUESDAY AND WEDNES-
DAY FOLLOWING YOUR VISIT.

THE REPORTER HAD PROMISED MRS. ROJAS THAT HE WOULD
ALLOW US TO CHECK THE ARTICLES BEFORE HE SENT THEM
TO PRESS. HOWEVER, WITH TYPICAL REPORTER-LIKE CONFI-
DENCE IN HIS OWN ARTICLES, HE PUBLISHED THEM WITHOUT
GIVING US A CHANCE TO GO OVER THE MISTAKES. AT LEAST
HE SEEMS TO HAVE DONE A FAIRLY GOOD JOB IN EXPLAINING
THE POINT OF SOME OF THE PROBLEMS INVOLVED IN USING
CORTISONE FOR EVERYTHING FROM INGROWN TOENAILS TO
DANDRUFF. MRS. ROJAS REGRETTED VERY MUCH THE MAN'S
FAILURE TO CO-OPERATE, AND WE BOTH HOPE THAT THE ERRORS
DO NOT MAKE TOO SERIOUS A MISREPRESENTATION OF YOUR
POINTS.

IT WAS AN UNUSUAL PLEASURE TO HAVE LUNCH WITH YOU AND
TO ACCOMPANY YOU ON THIS INTERVIEW WHICH FOR YOU WAS
VERY DULL, BUT FOR THE REST OF US MOST INTERESTING.

WE ARE LOOKING FORWARD TO YOUR RETURN TO HAVANA WHEN WE
MAY HAVE A CHANCE FOR ANOTHER VISIT WITH YOU AND MRS. HENCH.
div1.closer:
SINCERELY YOURS, JAMES D. BAKER
HEADMASTER JDB:LMP
ENCS.
